Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Birnirk prehistory and the emergence of Inupiaq Culture in Northwestern Alaska, archaeological and anthropological perspectives.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will explore the question of the origin of Inupiaq culture in northwestern Alaska at the end of the first millennium AD. The project will document the cultural histories, social interactions, population diversity and dispersal, and environmental changes from data collected at Cape Espenberg and in relation to the greater Bering Strait and Arctic regions. The research team will work together with community members in Shishmaref to conduct archaeological excavation, paleoecology and ancient DNA research to better understand who were the people that first settled the area around AD 1000, when and from where they came, and in what environmental conditions these events took place. At the same time they will work with cultural advisers and Shishmaref community members who have ancestral ties to the area to explore how material culture and landscape is interpreted to talk about the past and tell history. The project will promote progress of science and education by conducting basic research and developing new methods in the several research fields involved. By insuring and promoting proper conservation of artifacts the project, will increase awareness and capacity to preserve the growing catalog of perishable organic artifacts, increasingly exposed due to eroding coastal and thawing permafrost. By including indigenous perspectives on material culture, the research will promote an archaeology that is more receptive to multiple voices. The project will also foster national and international collaborations between four US research institutes, a French University (U. of Panth√©on Sorbonne), a rural Alaska community and a regional non-profit corporation. Associated with the project a variety of initiatives represent opportunities in research, education and training for a number of underrepresented Alaska minorities, women, and undergraduate and graduate students.

The aims of this multidisciplinary program of research is to explore human interaction, settlement history, climate and landscape dynamics in relation to the Birnirk archaeological complex at ca. AD 1000. After a period of hiatus, Birnirk site KTZ-304 at Cape Espenberg (Inuigniq) was occupied at a pivotal cultural and environmental moment in Northwest Alaska and the larger Bering Sea region, just before AD 1000 and prior to the emergence of Inupiaq culture around AD 1300. Cape Espenberg is a key location for this cultural history both because of the presence of Ipiutak, Birnik and Thule archaeological sites and as ancestral land of today's Kigiqtaamiut of Shishmaref. Interrelated and integrated analytical approaches involving cultural and physical anthropology, archaeology and paleoecology will (a) form the framework for continued excavation at site KTZ-304 (b) contribute to study architectural features, archaeofauna, ceramics, and artifacts in order to elucidate social networks, subsistence systems and technology, and to understand the impact of climate and resource availability on peoples activities, decisions and movements; (c) guide the collecting of paleoenvironmental data through targeted sampling of swales and ridges to date dune ridge stabilization, reconstruct terrestrial vegetation and map the location of the ocean relative to the site; (d) integrate ancient DNA (aDNA) studies to establish the broader genetic relationships of Inuit societies in the region and beyond; (e) explore how Kigiqtaamiut interpret material culture to understand the past, narrate history and generate knowledge (f) foster a dialog on the role of material culture today in the community of Shishmaref and in between the Kigiqtaamiut and the scientists to construct more reflexive interpretations of the past, and thus (g) advance understanding of the origin of Inupiaq culture through the development of a high-resolution chronology of settlement and landscape formation, cultural shift and climate variation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In October 2019, the CU subaward to the Birnirk Prehistory project completed two years of archaeological excavation within two adjacent houses within the dunes of Cape Espenberg, and conducted geological research on the neighboring dunes. Extensive excavations within two exceptionally well preserved driftwood structures established that two different households, one Birnirk and one early Thule, occupied adjacent portions of the same coastal dune between AD 1150 and 1400, a period of considerable cultural and climatic turbulence across  northwest Alaska, that led to an intensification of whaling.  In brief, the project has established that a regional shift was catalyzed by a migration from Siberia toward Alaska, marked by high mobility strategy and extensive trade relations evident in common technologies, styles and idiosyncratic cultural practices. The centuries of the Birnirk occupation were marked by profound undulations in storms and cooler weather, serving as climatic constraints on cultural development and were investigated through environmental proxy data, including sediment cores and plant macrofossil data, collected by University of Alaska researchers Maio and Bigelow.  Dr. Mason assisted in the interpretation of geomorphic proxy datasets. The responses of the Birnirk and Thule people were recorded within the objects discarded within and adjacent to the two houses. Dr. Mason focused on the analysis the harpoon heads and decorative motifs from both houses, establishing that nearly identical objects occurred across over 1000 km the site, with special similarities to Point Barrow, Alaska and across northern  Chukotka. Different subsistence strategies were evident in the two houses, with a shift from a whaling and caribou hunting economy to one with a greater reliance on ringed seal. The artifact collection shows a change from the Birnirk high mobility, pan-regional perspective to a more focused Thule economy.  Artistic representations, however, records that caribou procurement maintained its cultural importance in the Thule house. The genetic affinities of human remains found within the structures reflect both the Siberian affinities of the Birnirk culture and the commonalities with the widespread Thule culture that followed it. A detailed discussion of the archaeological researches will be described in the subaward reports of the collaborative researchers at three institutions, including the University of Alaska (PI, Claire Alix, Chris Maio and Nancy Bigelow) and University of Kansas (PI, Dennis O'Rourke) and the Portland State University (Shelby Anderson); all of which remain will remain active throughout 2019 and 2020. 

In total, the project resulted in the excavation, curation and analyses of a collection and database on organic, lithic and ceramic artifacts, many thousand animal bones, the analyses of ancient DNA. The conservation and recording of the artifact collection is ongoing at the UAF, directed by Susanne Grieve. The analysis of ancient DNA, zooarchaeology and isotopes involve KU subawared to O'Rourke, and Norman, post-doc researcher. The project conducted community workshops in Shishmaref, and presented findings at professional venues, including the Alaska Anthropological Association and the Society for American Archaeology, as well as international conferences in Canada, France and South Korea. The results of the project were discussed on National Public Radio and are the subject of a full-length video produced by an independent contractor, Far North Films, directed by Sarah Betcher; this project is ongoing.

The CU subaward supported the co-Principal Investigator, Owen K. Mason, in the field, as co-director, geologist and stratigrapher. Dr. Mason analyzed stratigraphic contextual relationships of the architectural features and the geomorphic setting of the houses by maintaining a detailed excavation log   Studies of soil micromorphology and dendrochronology are underway by graduate students at the University of Paris (Sorbonne), participants in the UAF component, directed by Claire Alix. Detailed plan views and a three-dimensional model of the excavation was produced by University of Paris personnel. The regional relationships s were clarified by ceramic studies, accompanied by residue analyses; within the PSU subaward to Shelby Anderson.

 

The CU subaward involved several support activities for the collaborative project: funding travel and compensating the co-PI of the project.  The submission of the radiocarbon samples was a prime responsibility of the CU subaward, conducted with collaboration of the PI, Claire Alix of the University of Alaska Fairbanks and Lauren Norman, post-doc researcher at the University of Kansas.  In all, over 20 samples were assayed for chronometric and isotopic concentation by several laboratories and are in the process of statistical and contextual analyses.  Preliminary analyses indicate that the two houses were not occupied at the same time. About 20 additional samples were submitted through the UAF subaward on unexcavated houses adjacent to those excavated.  Dr. Mason obtained stratigraphic data from those houses and the forthcoming dating results will elucidate the timing of the entire occupation on the same ridge.

 

The final report, due in October 2020, of the remaining subawards will discuss the final conclusions of the larger Birnirk Prehistory project.
